rComments: One of the worst, no, the worst class Ive ever taken at the UC. The main point is that instead of imparting knowledge of physics to non-science majors, he overburdens and in the end wastes everyones (read, mine) time. He loses homework assignments and it is impossible to get credit or have him take credit for his errors. He is disorganized.

sure he's a nice guy, but i don't think i'm alone by saying that he makes no sense. his tests are killer (don't let "openbook/opennote" fool you), and his demonstrations are entertaining but very confusing.

Terry had really interesting demonstrations but I had no idea what they were supposed to be illustrating. I never understood much of his lectures and was never sure what to take down for notes.  I did pretty badly on his exams because of this, as did everyone else I knew in the class, fortunately he grades on a curve, so I ended up getting a B.

Terry does not know what he is talking about. When he isn't busy telling the class that "everything is made up of marbles," he is saying such rediculus things like "air bubbles in one's bloodstream is not unhealthy." Schalk needs to organize his "lectures" and know what he is talking about.

Schalk is a smart man, but often times doesn't know what he is talking about. He's also kind of a flake and has not responded to my emails and has blown me off in class. He can also be quite arrogant if you call his errors. He's okay, but not great.

Terry's conceptual physics class is very straightforward and clear. At first I thought his structure was a little strange, with sounds and waves as the first unit, but it tied itself together later in the course. Eager to clarify topics and uses some cool in-class experiments to prove concepts.
my most favorite class this quater!  Schalk is awesome and makes the topic interesting even for people who are not science majors.
